text: <@U69BL50BF> Hello Chris, I was planning to apply to GSOC this year and was curious about the project, "Multi-start Optimization Methods" and saw you were a mentor for the same. So may I ask, what is expected from this project? And what would a strong competitive application look like for this project? My contributions as of now consist of coding a new method for multiple shooting in DiffEqFlux which was guided by you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hello Chris, I was planning to apply to GSOC this year and was curious about the project, "Multi-start Optimization Methods" and saw you were a mentor for the same. So may I ask, what is expected from this project? And what would a strong competitive application look like for this project? My contributions as of now consist of coding a new method for multiple shooting in DiffEqFlux which was guided by you

text: Hi <@U01KF8TJEN4>, I will be co-mentoring this project with Chris. This project can go in different directions. You can work on developing MultistartOptimization.jl, e.g. adding parallelism, different sampling algorithms, connecting it to Nonconvex.jl. You can work on HyperOpt.jl to develop the algorithm referenced in <https://github.com/baggepinnen/Hyperopt.jl/issues/6>. You can address some other issues there, implement Sobol sequence sampling and TikTak from MultistartOptimization.jl into HyperOpt.jl, connect it to GalacticOptim.jl or Nonconvex.jl. You can find another algorithm that’s not available in either of these packages and implement them. You can use MultistartOptimization.jl and/or HyperOpt.jl with Turing.jl for optimising Bayesian inference algorithms. There are many possibilities. A strong application would have a few PRs to prove your Julia experience and a detailed project proposal showing you have studied the project requirements and packages you will be developing and have done your homework.

elements.text: Hi

You can find another algorithm that’s not available in either of these packages and implement them. You can use MultistartOptimization.jl and/or HyperOpt.jl with Turing.jl for optimising Bayesian inference algorithms. There are many possibilities. A strong application would have a few PRs to prove your Julia experience and a detailed project proposal showing you have studied the project requirements and packages you will be developing and have done your homework.
pinging
the author of HyperOpt

text: Hi Mohamed, I am super thrilled to see you as a co-mentor. Thank you so much for replying and sharing the valuable suggestions. I was going through research paper mentioned in the issue <https://github.com/baggepinnen/Hyperopt.jl/issues/6> and it seems very interesting and I'm excited about it. I'll thoroughly go through it a few more times and also explore other ideas you mentioned. Thank you again!

text:
Hello <@U01KF8TJEN4> and <@U85JBUGGP>
I welcome new contributers to Hyperopt with open arms! I should be upfront with the fact that Hyperopt has collected some amount of technical debt and could use a redesign of the internals. It's still a fairly small package though so it shouldn't be too much of an issue. I've detailed some ideas around it in this comment
<https://github.com/baggepinnen/Hyperopt.jl/issues/41#issuecomment-752705523>
but I'm open to having it done in other ways as well.

elements.text: Hello
and

It's still a fairly small package though so it shouldn't be too much of an issue. I've detailed some ideas around it in this comment
but I'm open to having it done in other ways as well.

text: Given that this is a GSoC project, it’s hard to have refactoring as a goal because it’s not super measurable. I would be happy to help with that at some point after GSoC though since I might need HyperOpt for some of the stuff I do so I want to get my hands dirty.

elements.text: Given that this is a GSoC project, it’s hard to have refactoring as a goal because it’s not super measurable. I would be happy to help with that at some point after GSoC though since I might need HyperOpt for some of the stuff I do so I want to get my hands dirty.

text: also refactoring isn't super technically satisfying. Instead, look for something that has a really nice paper already written, something that you feel has a very nice self-contained description. Find 3 of those, open clear issues, and that's a GSoC

elements.text: also refactoring isn't super technically satisfying. Instead, look for something that has a really nice paper already written, something that you feel has a very nice self-contained description. Find 3 of those, open clear issues, and that's a GSoC

text: Refactoring will likely happen during the project, it's only natural. But it shouldn't be the project.

elements.text: Refactoring will likely happen during the project, it's only natural. But it shouldn't be the project.

text:
> Refactoring will likely happen during the project
I don’t think that should happen ideally unless the student is already somewhat comfortable with the design of the package developed which is usually not the case.

text:
Hi Mohamed and Chris, for the "Multi-Start Optimization Methods" GSoC project I was thinking of implementing the BOHB algorithm in Hyperopt.jl and CRS2-LM (Controlled Random Search with Local Mutation), MLSL (Multi-Level Single-Linkage) in MultistartOptimization.jl.
What are your thoughts on this and how does this sound to you? :sweat_smile:

elements.text:

What are your thoughts on this and how does this sound to you?
Sounds good to me
